subject: Re: "Clearscript" alphabet
msgSnippet: I have examined your alphabet and it is an excellent concept, but I have a couple of issues with it. First, there is no need to have three height levels of
messageBody:
I have examined your alphabet and it is an excellent concept, but I
have a couple of issues with it.

First, there is no need to have three height levels of vowels. I
note that you have placed them relative to their classified position
as judged by the IPA. What you need to realize, however, is that
nobody really thinks about their vowels in terms of front, mid, mid-
front, etcetera when they say them, so any mnemonic value that might
be gained by placing the vowels at varying horizontal positions is
lost.

Further, it is difficult to write this way. Having letters at the
upper parallel or writing line is fine, but letters in the middle
will lack consistency because there is nothing against which to judge
them. Ergo, they will tend to float upwards or downwards. It is my
opinion that you should simply move all vowels down to the writing
line -- they are distinct enough from one another as they are. This
will also make it easier to read the LED format.

-Andy

--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, "Michael A. Rouse"
<mrouse@c...> wrote:
> I'm not sure if anyone is interested, but I've created a phonetic
> (phonemic?) alphabet for English in the same vein as the Shavian
> alphabet and Quikscript. As a nod to the latter, I call it
> "Clearscript," and it's available at:
>
> www.mrouse.com/rousalph.htm
>
> There's only a tiny bit of material, mainly the alphabet itself and
an
> IPA chart using the alphabet, plus a brief explanation of some of
the
> features, but some might find it interesting. Any suggestions or
> improvements can be sent to mrouse@m... Thanks!
>
> Mike Rouse

I have examined your alphabet and it is an excellent concept, but I 
have a couple of issues with it.

First, there is no need to have three height levels of vowels.  I 
note that you have placed them relative to their classified position 
as judged by the IPA.  What you need to realize, however, is that 
nobody really thinks about their vowels in terms of front, mid, mid-
front, etcetera when they say them, so any mnemonic value that might 
be gained by placing the vowels at varying horizontal positions is 
lost.  

Further, it is difficult to write this way.  Having letters at the 
upper parallel or writing line is fine, but letters in the middle 
will lack consistency because there is nothing against which to judge 
them.  Ergo, they will tend to float upwards or downwards.  It is my 
opinion that you should simply move all vowels down to the writing 
line -- they are distinct enough from one another as they are.  This 
will also make it easier to read the LED format.

-Andy

> I'm not sure if anyone is interested, but I've created a phonetic

> alphabet and Quikscript. As a nod to the latter, I call it
